questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of excessive tearing, photophobia, and large eyes noticed since infancy. Examination reveals bilateral corneal edema and a horizontal corneal diameter 14 mm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B) Congenital glaucoma: This is the correct answer.

  • Buphthalmos (enlarged eye) is a hallmark of congenital glaucoma due to elevated intraocular pressure in infancy.
  • The classic triad of congenital glaucoma includes tearing (epiphora), photophobia, and blepharospasm.
  • The increased corneal diameter (>12 mm in infants), corneal edema, and an increased cup-to-disc ratio further support the diagnosis.
  • Option A) Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome: This is a developmental anomaly characterized by anterior segment dysgenesis, often with features such as corectopia, iris hypoplasia, and posterior embryotoxon.
  • It does not typically cause buphthalmos or elevated intraocular pressure from birth.
  • Option C) Peters anomaly: This refers to central corneal opacity due to abnormal development of the anterior segment, but it does not cause buphthalmos or elevated intraocular pressure.
  • Option D) Sclerocornea: This is a condition where the cornea becomes opaque and blends with the sclera, but it does not involve elevated intraocular pressure or buphthalmos.

Congenital glaucoma :

  • is typically diagnosed in the first few years of life and results from improper development of the anterior chamber angle, leading to impaired aqueous outflow and elevated intraocular pressure.
  • This increased pressure causes eye enlargement (buphthalmos) due to the elasticity of the infantile sclera.
  • Treatment is primarily surgical, with procedures like goniotomy or trabeculotomy.

#congenital glaucoma #buphthalmos

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, page number:327.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with a history of blunt trauma to the right eye. On slit-lamp examination, a stellate-shaped opacity is seen in the lens cortex. In another patient, a 32-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes presents with rapidly progressing cataracts, characterized by multiple small opacities in the lens cortex resembling snowflakes. Lastly, a 50-year-old patient presents with iridescent, multicolored opacities in the lens cortex resembling Christmas tree ornaments



Which of the following is the correct match between the cataract type and its associated condition?
questions.solution:
• A) Rosette cataract - Diabetes mellitus: Rosette cataracts are typically seen after blunt trauma, not diabetes. They form a stellate or rosette pattern in the lens cortex.
  • B) Snowflake cataract - Blunt trauma: Snowflake cataracts are commonly associated with poorly controlled diabetes, particularly in younger patients. They consist of small, white cortical opacities resembling snowflakes.
  • C) Christmas tree cataract - Myotonic dystrophy: Christmas tree cataracts are associated with myotonic dystrophy and are characterized by multicolored, iridescent opacities in the lens, resembling the decorations on a Christmas tree.
  • D) Rosette cataract - Steroid use: Steroid use is more commonly associated with posterior subcapsular cataracts, not rosette cataracts.
  • E) Snowflake cataract - Hypocalcemia: Hypocalcemia may cause cataracts, but the snowflake pattern is specifically linked to diabetes mellitus.

Overview:

  • Rosette cataract: Seen in blunt trauma; has a characteristic stellate or rosette pattern in the anterior or posterior lens cortex.
  • Snowflake cataract: Seen in uncontrolled diabetes, especially in younger individuals; characterized by cortical opacities resembling snowflakes.
  • Christmas tree cataract: Associated with myotonic dystrophy, featuring iridescent, polychromatic opacities that resemble Christmas tree ornaments.

#cataract #lens changes #types of cataract

Reference: Yanoff & Duker's Ophthalmology, 5th Edition, page number:538.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with a sudden, painless loss of vision in his right eye. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On fundoscopic examination, the following findings are seen:

Given this presentation, which of the following is most likely not a complication of the condition he is suffering from?
questions.solution:
• D) Retinal detachment: Correct. Retinal detachment is not a typical complication of CRVO. The most common complications involve neovascularization, macular edema, and hemorrhages.
  • A) Neovascular glaucoma: This is a known complication of ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) due to the development of neovascularization of the iris, which can lead to secondary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • B) Vitreous hemorrhage: Vitreous hemorrhage can occur as a result of retinal neovascularization, which is a common complication in ischemic CRVO.
  • C) Macular edema: Macular edema is the most common cause of vision loss in CRVO. It results from fluid leakage due to retinal vein blockage and is seen in both ischemic and non-ischemic CRVO.

CRVO:

  • often divided into ischemic and non-ischemic types.
  • Ischemic CRVO has a higher risk of severe complications such as neovascular glaucoma and retinal neovascularization, while non-ischemic CRVO is typically less severe but can still result in significant vision loss due to macular edema.

#CRVO #retinal vein occlusion

Reference:Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, page number: 468.

choices.text: Shifting fluid with no retinal breaks

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of flashes and floaters in her right eye, followed by the sensation of a curtain-like shadow descending over her visual field. She denies pain. Her past medical history includes high myopia and cataract surgery 5 years ago. On fundoscopic examination, below findings are noted. Fluorescein angiography shows no abnormal vascular leakage.

Which of the following findings would exclude the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The above shown fundus is of rhegmatogenous RD with horseshoe tear.
  • Option B) Shifting fluid with no retinal breaks: Correct. This finding is characteristic of exudative retinal detachment, not rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • Exudative detachments occur due to fluid accumulation under the retina from inflammatory, vascular, or neoplastic processes and do not involve retinal tears or breaks.
  • Option A) Presence of retinal neovascularization: Retinal neovascularization can occur secondary to various retinal conditions such as proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which may result in tractional detachment, but its presence does not exclude rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, especially if tears are present.
  • Option C) History of high myopia: High myopia is a significant risk factor for rhegmatogenous retinal detachment due to the increased likelihood of peripheral retinal degeneration and retinal tears.
  • Option D) Retinal tears at the periphery: Peripheral retinal tears are a hallmark of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, which occurs when vitreous fluid enters through these breaks, leading to retinal separation.

Overview:

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment and is characterized by a retinal break that allows vitreous fluid to enter the subretinal space. The typical symptoms include photopsia (flashes), floaters, and a curtain-like shadow over the visual field. It can be differentiated from other types of retinal detachment as follows:

  • Tractional retinal detachment: Caused by pulling forces on the retina due to fibrovascular proliferation, commonly seen in diabetic retinopathy or retinopathy of prematurity. It lacks retinal breaks but can cause detachment due to traction forces.

  • Exudative (serous) retinal detachment: Characterized by subretinal fluid without retinal breaks. It is caused by inflammation, neoplasms, or vascular disorders, and fluid shifts with head positioning.

#retinal detachment #types of RD #causes of rhegmatogenous RD #retina

Reference: Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, page number: 456.

questions.text: A 25-year-old contact lens wearer presents with severe eye pain, redness, and blurred vision for the past week. She reports improper contact lens hygiene, often using tap water to clean her lenses. On slit-lamp examination, shown findings are noted. Her symptoms appear disproportionate to the clinical findings. For the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The correct answer is Acanthamoeba keratitis is a severe, often painful corneal infection caused by the protozoan Acanthamoeba, commonly associated with improper contact lens hygiene or exposure to contaminated water.
  • The organism can penetrate the corneal epithelium, causing characteristic ring-shaped stromal infiltrates, which may appear later in the disease. The pain is often disproportionate to the clinical findings.
  • Confocal microscopy is a non-invasive imaging technique that can help visualize Acanthamoeba cysts in the corneal stroma, making it one of the first-line investigations for suspected Acanthamoeba keratitis. This method can quickly identify the presence of the pathogen without invasive procedures.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B. Corneal biopsy: While this is an option for confirming diagnosis in severe or resistant cases, it is more invasive and generally not the first investigation.
  • Option C. Gram stain of corneal scrapings: Acanthamoeba cysts are not visible with a Gram stain, which is more suited for bacterial infections.
  • Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for herpes simplex virus: This would be useful in cases of viral keratitis but not for detecting Acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba Keratitis:

  • Etiology: Caused by the free-living protozoan Acanthamoeba. Risk factors include poor contact lens hygiene, exposure to contaminated water (e.g., tap water, swimming pools).
  • Clinical Features: Severe eye pain, redness, photophobia, tearing, blurred vision, and a ring-shaped corneal infiltrate (in later stages). Pain is often out of proportion to the visible clinical findings.
  • Diagnosis: Confocal microscopy, corneal scraping with culture on non-nutrient agar, PCR for Acanthamoeba.
  • Treatment: Early treatment involves antiamoebic agents such as polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) or chlorhexidine. In advanced cases, a corneal transplant may be required.
  • Prognosis: Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for preserving vision. Delayed diagnosis can lead to severe corneal damage and even loss of vision.

#acanthamoeba keratitis #ring ulcer #contact lens ulcer #cornea

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, page number. 2016. Chapter 7, Corneal and External Eye Disease, page number: 185.

choices.text: Acyclovir 400 mg oral five times a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment five times a day
Acyclovir 400 mg oral three times a day + Acyclovir 5% eye ointment three times a day
Acyclovir 800 mg oral twice a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment twice a day
Acyclovir 400 mg oral five times a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment three times a day

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a painful red eye, photophobia, and reduced vision in her right eye. She has a history of recurrent cold sores and reports that she recently experienced another outbreak. Slit-lamp examination with Fluorescein staining reveals below findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment regimen for her condition?
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) keratitis is the most common form of viral keratitis and can present as dendritic ulcers on the cornea, which are characteristic for HSV epithelial keratitis.

  • The treatment regimen typically involves Acyclovir in both oral and topical forms to inhibit viral replication. For active HSV epithelial keratitis, the recommended dose of Acyclovir is:
    • Acyclovir 400 mg orally, five times a day, for 7-21 days, followed by maintenance dose of 400mg two times a day with monitoring of LFT and RFT..
    • Acyclovir 3% ointment, applied five times a day, for 7-10 days.

This combined approach helps ensure effective viral suppression both systemically and locally on the eye.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B. Acyclovir 400 mg oral three times a day + Acyclovir 5% eye ointment three times a day: This dosage regimen is insufficient for treating active HSV keratitis and might not provide adequate viral suppression.
  • Option C. Acyclovir 800 mg oral twice a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment twice a day: The oral dose is typically higher for other indications like herpes zoster, not for HSV keratitis. Topical application twice a day is insufficient.
  • Option D. Acyclovir 400 mg oral five times a day + Acyclovir 3% eye ointment three times a day: Although the oral dose here is adequate, the topical ointment needs to be applied more frequently to manage the active viral infection effectively.

Viral Keratitis (HSV Keratitis):

  • Etiology: HSV is the most common cause of viral keratitis. It can manifest as primary infection or reactivation of latent virus.
  • Clinical Features: Pain, redness, photophobia, blurred vision, tearing, and dendritic corneal ulcers. Fluorescein staining highlights these ulcers, showing branching with terminal bulbs.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis is confirmed with slit-lamp examination and fluorescein staining. PCR can also be used for viral detection.
  • Treatment:
    • Acyclovir 400 mg oral five times a day for 7–10 days (or equivalent antivirals like valacyclovir or famciclovir).
    • Acyclovir 3% ointment five times a day for 7–10 days.
    • Topical corticosteroids are contraindicated in epithelial disease but may be used cautiously in stromal disease under antiviral coverage.
  • Complications: Delayed or inadequate treatment can result in corneal scarring, stromal keratitis, or even blindness.
  • Prevention: Long-term suppressive antiviral therapy may be recommended for patients with recurrent HSV keratitis to reduce the frequency of episodes.

#viral keratitis #dendritic ulcer #cornea

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. 2016. Chapter 7, Corneal and External Eye Disease, page number: 186.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with pain, redness, and decreased vision in his left eye for 10 days following a minor injury from a tree branch. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Fungal keratitis, also known as keratomycosis, is a serious and often vision-threatening corneal infection. It is commonly caused by trauma with organic material, especially in agricultural workers, and is more frequent in tropical and subtropical regions.

  • Natamycin 5% is the first-line topical antifungal for filamentous fungal infections such as those caused by Fusarium and Aspergillus It is administered as 1 drop every 1-2 hours initially and tapered based on clinical response. This drug is the only commercially available topical antifungal for ocular use.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option B. Fluconazole 0.3% eye drops: This is typically used for yeast infections such as those caused by Candida. It is not the first choice for filamentous fungi like Fusarium or Aspergillus, which are more common after trauma.
  • Option C. Acyclovir 3% eye ointment: Acyclovir is used for treating viral keratitis caused by herpes simplex virus, not fungal infections.
  • Ciprofloxacin 0.3% eye drops: This antibiotic is effective against bacterial keratitis, but it does not have antifungal properties and would not be effective against fungi.

Fungal Keratitis:

  • Etiology: Fungal keratitis is commonly caused by filamentous fungi (e.g., Fusarium, Aspergillus) and yeast-like fungi (e.g., Candida). Risk factors include trauma with vegetative material, contact lens use, and immunocompromised states.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Gradual onset of eye pain, redness, photophobia, tearing, and blurred vision.
    • Corneal features include a gray-white stromal infiltrate with feathery margins, satellite lesions, and a dry or rough surface.
    • Hypopyon is commonly seen.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Corneal scrapings for Gram stain, potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount, and culture on Sabouraud's agar to identify the fungal pathogen.
  • Treatment:
    • Natamycin 5% eye drops for filamentous fungi.
    • Voriconazole or amphotericin B may be used for resistant cases or if the infection involves deeper corneal layers.
    • Systemic antifungals like oral voriconazole or itraconazole may be added in severe cases or when scleral involvement is suspected.
  • Prognosis: Fungal keratitis can lead to serious complications such as corneal scarring and perforation if not treated promptly. Early diagnosis and aggressive antifungal therapy are critical to prevent vision loss.

#fungal keratitis #cornea

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. 2016. Chapter 7, Corneal and External Eye Disease, page number: 188.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from a rural area presents with dry eyes, night blindness, and foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva. His diet is predominantly based on rice and lacks fruits or vegetables. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The child presents with Bitot's spots, which are triangular, foamy, or foamy white lesions on the bulbar conjunctiva, usually seen in the temporal region. They are a sign of Vitamin A deficiency, often associated with a diet lacking in fruits, vegetables, and animal products. This condition is common in developing countries, especially in children with malnutrition.

  • The treatment for Vitamin A deficiency includes oral Vitamin A supplementation to replenish the body's stores and prevent further ocular and systemic complications. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends the following regimen:
    • For children aged 1-6 years: 200,000 IU of Vitamin A orally on two consecutive days, with a third dose 4-6 weeks later.
    • For infants under 1 year: 100,000 IU of Vitamin A orally on two consecutive days.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. Topical antibiotics: These are used for treating bacterial conjunctivitis or keratitis, not for treating Bitot's spots or Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Option B. Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF: This is used in the treatment of neovascular conditions like diabetic retinopathy or wet age-related macular degeneration, not for Vitamin A deficiency.
  • Option D. Topical corticosteroids: These may be used for inflammatory conditions of the eye, but they have no role in treating Vitamin A deficiency or Bitot’s spots.

Bitot's Spots and Vitamin A Deficiency:

  • Etiology: Bitot's spots are a sign of Vitamin A deficiency, which occurs due to inadequate dietary intake of Vitamin A-rich foods like green leafy vegetables, carrots, liver, and dairy products. It is particularly common in children and pregnant women in developing countries.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Bitot's spots: Foamy, whitish, triangular patches on the temporal conjunctiva, typically in both eyes.
    • Other symptoms of Vitamin A deficiency include xerophthalmia (dry eyes), night blindness, and in severe cases, corneal ulcers and keratomalacia.
  • Diagnosis: Based on clinical presentation and dietary history. Blood tests may reveal low serum retinol levels.
  • Treatment:
    • Oral Vitamin A supplementation is the mainstay of treatment.
    • The WHO guidelines for Vitamin A supplementation are tailored based on the child's age and the severity of deficiency. Vitamin A supplementation is crucial in preventing blindness and other systemic complications, such as increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Prevention: Ensuring adequate dietary intake of Vitamin A through fortified foods or regular supplementation in high-risk populations can prevent the development of Bitot's spots and other deficiency-related complications.

#Vitamin A deficiency #Bitot's spots #night blindness #xerophthalmia

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. 2016. Chapter 14, Nutritional and Metabolic Eye Disease, page number. 610.

choices.text: Wilson's disease, copper deposition in Descemet's membrane
Hemochromatosis, iron deposition in the corneal stroma
Multiple sclerosis, demyelination of the optic nerve
Vitamin A deficiency, lipid deposition in the cornea

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in speech, tremors, and clumsiness in movements over the past year. He also reports a recent change in personality with increased irritability and difficulty in concentrating. His liver function tests show elevated transaminases. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the primary underlying cause of this ocular finding?
questions.solution:
Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring is a brownish or golden ring observed at the periphery of the cornea, most prominent at the superior and inferior poles. It results from the deposition of copper in Descemet's membrane of the cornea, seen in Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration). Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, leading to impaired copper excretion and accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, and cornea.

  • The KF ring is usually detected via slit-lamp examination and is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, especially when seen in conjunction with neurological and hepatic symptoms, such as tremors, psychiatric disturbances, and liver dysfunction.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hemochromatosis, iron deposition in the corneal stroma: Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron absorption and deposition, primarily affecting the liver, heart, and skin, but it does not cause corneal deposits.
  • Multiple sclerosis, demyelination of the optic nerve: While multiple sclerosis affects the central nervous system, causing optic neuritis, it does not lead to corneal findings such as a KF ring.
  • Vitamin A deficiency, lipid deposition in the cornea: Vitamin A deficiency can cause xerophthalmia and Bitot's spots, but it does not cause a KF ring or copper deposition.

Kayser-Fleischer (KF) Ring and Wilson's Disease:

  • Etiology: The KF ring is seen in Wilson's disease, an autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7B Copper accumulates in various tissues due to defective biliary excretion.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Ocular: The KF ring, a brownish-golden ring at the periphery of the cornea, is caused by copper deposition in Descemet's membrane. It is detectable with slit-lamp examination.
    • Neurological: Movement disorders (tremors, dystonia), psychiatric changes (irritability, personality change), and speech difficulties.
    • Hepatic: Liver dysfunction ranging from mild transaminitis to cirrhosis.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Slit-lamp examination: Detection of the KF ring.
    • Serum ceruloplasmin: Low levels.
    • 24-hour urinary copper excretion: Elevated levels.
    • Liver biopsy: Increased hepatic copper concentration.
  • Treatment:
    • Chelation therapy: Drugs such as penicillamine or trientine promote urinary copper excretion.
    • Zinc supplementation: Reduces intestinal copper absorption.
    • Liver transplantation may be considered in cases of fulminant hepatic failure or advanced cirrhosis.
  • Prognosis: Early diagnosis and treatment can prevent severe neurological and hepatic damage.

#KF ring #wilson's disease

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th edi5. 2016. Chapter 7, Corneal and External Eye Disease, page number. 200.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of one eye deviating intermittently. The parents have noticed the issue for the past few months, particularly when the child is tired. On examination, the cover test reveals an alternating esotropia. Which of the following instruments is used to measure the angle of deviation in this child?
questions.solution:
• Synoptophore is an instrument used to measure the angle of deviation in patients with squint (strabismus). It can also be used for sensory tests such as measuring fusion and stereopsis.
  • The child places their chin on the rest, and images are presented to each eye separately. The angle of squint (esotropia or exotropia) is measured by adjusting the images until they are perceived as aligned by the patient.

Explanation of other options:

  • B. Retinoscope: This instrument is used to measure refractive error and determine the need for corrective lenses. It is not used to measure squint or ocular deviation.
  • C. Worth 4-dot test: This is a fusion test used to assess whether a patient has normal binocular vision, suppression, or diplopia, but it does not measure the angle of deviation.
  • D. Maddox rod: This test is used to identify heterophoria or latent squint by disrupting binocular vision and is useful in determining the alignment of the eyes, but it does not directly measure the squint angle.

Above shown is the cover test, used to diagnose latent squint and manifest degree of deviation, to break fusion.

Instruments Used for Detecting Squint in Children:

  1. Synoptophore:
    • Used to measure the angle of deviation in strabismus and assess binocular function.
    • It also evaluates fusional amplitudes and is helpful in therapeutic exercises.
  2. Prism Cover Test:
    • The gold standard for measuring the angle of deviation.
    • Prisms of varying strength are placed before the deviating eye while performing the cover test to neutralize the deviation.
  3. Maddox Rod:
    • Used to detect heterophoria (latent squint) and estimate the angle of deviation in cases of small squints or phorias.
    • Disrupts fusion by presenting one eye with a line image and the other with a point of light.
  4. Worth 4-Dot Test:
    • Assesses binocular vision and suppression.
    • The patient wears red-green glasses and views a four-dot target; depending on how many dots are seen, the examiner can determine whether the child has normal binocular vision, suppression, or diplopia.
  5. Hirschberg Test:
    • A quick screening test to detect strabismus by observing the light reflex on the cornea. The position of the reflex indicates the presence of a squint and provides a rough estimate of the deviation.

#tests in strabismus #measurement of squint #maddox rod #cover test

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. 2016. Chapter 15, Strabismus, page number: 682.

It can be performed without topical anesthetic
The measurement is not affected by the patient's posture

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is referred to an ophthalmology clinic for evaluation of suspected glaucoma. During the examination, the ophthalmologist decides to measure his intraocular pressure using below shown tonometry. Which of the following statements regarding this method is most accurate?
questions.solution:
• A) It is influenced significantly by corneal thickness: Goldmann applanation tonometry measurements are affected by corneal thickness; a thicker cornea can yield falsely elevated IOP readings, while a thinner cornea can result in falsely low measurements. This relationship is crucial for accurate interpretation of tonometry results.
  • Option B) It can be performed without topical anesthetic: Goldmann tonometry requires topical anesthetic to ensure patient comfort and prevent reflex tearing, which can interfere with the measurement.
  • Option C) The measurement is not affected by the patient's posture: While Goldmann tonometry is generally reliable, measurements can vary slightly with different postures, particularly if the patient is not seated upright.
  • Option D) It is the least accurate method for measuring intraocular pressure: Goldmann tonometry is considered the gold standard for IOP measurement and is more accurate than many other methods, such as non-contact or rebound tonometry.

Goldmann Applanation Tonometry:


  • Mechanism: Measures the pressure required to flatten a small area of the cornea.
  • Indications: Primarily used for diagnosing and monitoring glaucoma.
  • Advantages: High accuracy and reproducibility; considered the gold standard.
  • Disadvantages: Requires topical anesthesia and can be affected by corneal properties (thickness, curvature).

The correct answer is The Goldmann applanation tonometer (GAT) is considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP).

other options for IOP measurement:

  • Non-contact tonometer: This is also known as the air-puff tonometer, which estimates IOP by releasing a puff of air onto the cornea and measuring the corneal deformation. It is less accurate than Goldmann tonometry, especially in patients with abnormal corneal properties.
  • Schiotz tonometer: This is an older, indentation-type tonometer that measures the depth of corneal indentation caused by a known weight. It is less commonly used today due to its limitations in accuracy compared to applanation tonometry.
  • Perkins tonometer: This portable version of the Goldmann tonometer is used primarily in children or bedridden patients.
  • It functions similarly to the Goldmann tonometer but is more practical in certain clinical situations.
  • It is not considered the gold standard, but it provides reliable results.
  • Tono pen:: Portable, hand-held device based on applanation. It is useful in uncooperative patients, such as those with ocular trauma or corneal scars.
  • Advantages: Practical for use in various settings, including emergency care.
  • Pascal Dynamic Contour Tonometer:
    • Principle: Measures IOP by matching the contour of the cornea rather than flattening it.
    • Use: Provides more accurate measurements in eyes with corneal irregularities (e.g., post-refractive surgery).

#Tonometry #IOP measurement #glaucoma

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. 2016. Chapter 10, Glaucoma, page number: 318.

choices.text: High-amplitude, mobile echoes in the vitreous cavity
V-shaped echogenic membranes attached at the optic disc and ora serrata
Hyper-reflective dome-shaped elevation of the posterior pole
Dense echoes localized within the vitreous chamber without retinal involvement

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a history of sudden, painless vision loss in his right eye. He reports no trauma and has no significant medical history. Upon examination, the fundus is not visible due to dense vitreous hemorrhage. A B-scan ultrasonography is performed. Which of the following findings would most likely suggest a diagnosis of retinal detachment?
questions.solution:
Retinal detachment appears as V-shaped echogenic membranes on B-scan ultrasonography.

  • The detached retina is often seen tethered at the optic nerve head and the ora serrata, with mobility noted upon ocular movements. This is the hallmark of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. High-amplitude, mobile echoes in the vitreous cavity: This finding is indicative of vitreous hemorrhage, which may be associated with retinal detachment but is not specific for it.
  • Option C. Hyper-reflective dome-shaped elevation of the posterior pole: This finding suggests a choroidal detachment, not a retinal detachment.

  • Option D. Dense echoes localized within the vitreous chamber without retinal involvement: This indicates vitreous opacities, such as hemorrhage or inflammation, without direct retinal pathology.

Specific B-Scan Ultrasonography Findings in the Eye:

  1. Retinal Detachment:
    • Appears as V-shaped, echogenic membranes attached at the optic nerve head and ora serrata.
    • The membrane may undulate with eye movement.
    • Common in conditions such as rhegmatogenous retinal detachment or tractional detachment in proliferative diabetic retinopathy.
  2. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
    • Presents as high-amplitude, mobile echoes within the vitreous cavity.
    • Can obscure retinal details but is frequently seen in diabetic retinopathy or trauma.
  3. Choroidal Detachment:
    • Appears as a dome-shaped, smooth, echogenic elevation of the choroid.
  4. Posterior Vitreous Detachment (PVD):
    • Presents as a linear, low-amplitude echo within the vitreous cavity, often detached from the retina but not involving retinal layers.
  5. Intraocular Foreign Body:
    • Presents as a highly reflective echo with acoustic shadowing behind the object.
    • Helpful in localizing foreign bodies that are not visible on clinical examination.
  6. Intraocular Tumors:
    • Choroidal melanoma may appear as a solid mass with low-to-medium internal reflectivity.
    • Retinoblastoma may show calcifications that produce strong echoes. Like in the below image.
  7. Endophthalmitis:
    • Presents as multiple low-to-moderate reflective echoes in the vitreous, often with poor visibility of the posterior segment due to the inflammatory exudates.

#USG B scan #ultrasonography of eye

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition. 2016. Chapter 10, Diagnostic Techniques, page number: 88.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of difficulty seeing on the right side of her visual field. She has no history of eye disease, but recently experienced a severe headache. On confrontation visual field testing, below findings are noted. Where is the most likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
• Macular sparing homonymous hemianopia typically results from damage to the contralateral occipital lobe, often due to ischemic strokes affecting the posterior cerebral artery (PCA).
  • The macula is spared because the occipital pole, responsible for macular vision, has a dual blood supply from both the posterior cerebral artery and, occasionally, the middle cerebral artery.
  • This dual supply helps preserve central vision despite damage to the rest of the visual field.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasm usually result in bitemporal hemianopia (loss of vision in the temporal halves of both visual fields), not macular sparing hemianopia.
  • Option B. Optic nerve: Optic nerve lesions cause monocular vision loss, not homonymous hemianopia.
  • Option D. Lateral geniculate body: Damage here can cause homonymous hemianopia, but macular sparing is more characteristic of occipital lobe lesions.

Neurological Visual Field Defects:

  1. Macular Sparing Homonymous Hemianopia:
    • Lesion location: Occipital cortex (usually due to posterior cerebral artery stroke).
    • Presentation: Loss of one side of the visual field (right or left) with preservation of central vision (macula), due to dual blood supply.
  2. Bitemporal Hemianopia:
    • Lesion location: Optic chiasma (most commonly from pituitary adenoma or craniopharyngioma).
    • Presentation: Loss of the temporal visual fields in both eyes, affecting peripheral vision.
  3. Monocular Vision Loss:
    • Lesion location: Optic nerve (due to optic neuritis, ischemia, or trauma).
    • Presentation: Complete vision loss in one eye.
  4. Homonymous Hemianopia:
    • Lesion location: Optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiation, or occipital cortex.
    • Presentation: Loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes (right or left), with or without macular sparing depending on the lesion site.
  5. Quadrantanopia:
    • Lesion location: Optic radiations or occipital lobe.
    • Presentation: Loss of a quarter of the visual field. A "pie-in-the-sky" defect (superior quadrantanopia) is due to damage to the Meyer's loop (temporal lobe), while a "pie-on-the-floor" defect (inferior quadrantanopia) results from parietal lobe involvement.
  6. Central Scotoma:
    • Lesion location: Optic nerve or macula.
    • Presentation: Loss of central vision, often associated with conditions such as optic neuritis or macular disease.

#neurological visual field #field loss #neuroophthal

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Chapter 9, Neuro-ophthalmology, page number: 450-453.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of intermittent deviation of the right eye, especially while focusing on near objects. The parents have noticed the deviation more frequently when the child is tired or concentrating on close tasks like reading. On examination, the child has moderate hyperopia, and the deviation is corrected with appropriate spectacles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Accommodative esotropia is the most common form of esotropia in children and is typically associated with hyperopia (farsightedness).
  • The inward deviation (esotropia) occurs due to excessive accommodation (focusing) effort required to see clearly.
  • This is particularly prominent when the child focuses on near objects. When corrective lenses are prescribed to correct the hyperopia, the esotropia typically resolves.

Explanation of other options:

  • Option A. Non-accommodative esotropia: This form of esotropia is unrelated to refractive errors and does not improve with spectacle correction.
  • Option B. Partially accommodative esotropia: In this condition, spectacle correction partially corrects the esotropia, but a residual deviation persists even with glasses.
  • Option D. Divergence insufficiency esotropia: This type occurs due to difficulty in diverging the eyes when looking at distant objects and is more common in older adults.

Accommodative Squint (Esotropia):

  1. Accommodative Esotropia:
    • Pathophysiology: Hyperopic children may overuse their accommodative mechanism to focus on near objects. The excessive accommodation leads to over-convergence, causing esotropia (inward deviation of one or both eyes).
    • Presentation:
      • Intermittent inward turning of the eye, especially during near work.
      • Often noticed between the ages of 2 to 4 years.
    • Diagnosis:
      • Hyperopia is detected on refraction.
      • Esotropia resolves with the use of appropriate spectacles (glasses that correct hyperopia).
    • Treatment: Corrective lenses to address hyperopia and, in some cases, bifocals for near work. If spectacles do not fully correct the esotropia, further treatment like prism glasses or surgery may be considered.
  2. Partially Accommodative Esotropia:
    • Pathophysiology: A combination of accommodative and non-accommodative mechanisms causing esotropia.
    • Treatment: Often requires both spectacle correction and surgery if a residual deviation persists.
  3. Non-Accommodative Esotropia:
    • Pathophysiology: Esotropia that is not related to accommodation or refractive error.
    • Treatment: Surgery is often required since spectacle correction does not improve the deviation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with diplopia and difficulty looking down, especially when reading or descending stairs. On examination, there is a noticeable left hypertropia, particularly when the patient looks to the right. The cover-uncover test reveals that the left eye drifts upward. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is Trochlear nerve palsy (fourth nerve palsy) results from dysfunction of the trochlear nerve, which innervates the superior oblique muscle. This muscle is responsible for downward gaze, particularly in adduction.

  • Patients typically present with vertical diplopia and difficulty with downward gaze, especially when looking down and to the side. The left hypertropia noted in the case is characteristic of left trochlear nerve palsy, where the affected eye (left eye) drifts upward when looking right.

Explanation of other options:

  • Oculomotor nerve palsy: This would present with ptosis, an enlarged pupil (in many cases), and difficulty in moving the eye in multiple directions, not just down.
  • Abducens nerve palsy: This involves the lateral rectus muscle, resulting in an inability to abduct the eye and horizontal diplopia.
  • Brown syndrome: This is characterized by a limitation in elevation of the affected eye, particularly in adduction, due to a restriction of the superior oblique tendon, not due to nerve palsy.

Fourth Nerve Palsy (Trochlear Nerve Palsy):

  1. Anatomy and Function:
    • The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, which depresses, intorts, and abducts the eye.
    • It is the only cranial nerve that exits the brainstem dorsally and has the longest intracranial course.
  2. Causes:
    • Congenital: Present at birth, may be associated with other ocular or neurological conditions.
    • Acquired:
    • Trauma (head injuries, especially those involving the posterior fossa).
    • Vascular causes (ischemic events, such as diabetes or hypertension).
    • Tumors or mass lesions affecting the nerve.
    • Inflammatory conditions (such as multiple sclerosis).
  3. Clinical Presentation:
    • Symptoms: Patients commonly experience diplopia that worsens with downward gaze and may describe difficulty with reading or stairs.
    • Signs:
    • Vertical misalignment (hypertropia) of the affected eye, which is more pronounced in adduction.
    • The head may tilt toward the side of the affected eye to compensate for the misalignment.
  4. Diagnosis:
    • Based on clinical examination, including the cover test and evaluation of eye movements.
    • Imaging studies (like MRI) may be indicated to assess for structural causes.
  5. Management:
    • Observation: Many cases improve spontaneously, especially if congenital.
    • Prism glasses: To help manage diplopia.
    • Surgery: In persistent cases or those with significant misalignment.

#FOURTH CN PALSY

Reference: Kanski JJ, Bowling B. Clinical Ophthalmology: A Systematic Approach. 8th Edition, Chapter 12, Neuro-ophthalmology, page number. 542-543.
